case_id: Kulwinder Singh v. State of Punjab and Another (2023) [Criminal Appeal No. 3418 of 2023 arising out of SLP (Crl.) No. 6976/2023]
facts: The case involves an appeal against the High Court of Punjab and Haryana's order dated 09.05.2023, which dismissed the appellant's application for anticipatory bail.
An FIR No. 14 was registered on 16.01.2023 at Police Station Sadar, District Fazilka.
The FIR was registered under Sections 452, 323, 354, 379B, 506, 148, 149 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).
The allegations state that on 16.01.2023 at about 11:00 AM, the appellant (Kulwinder Singh) along with other co-accused formed an unlawful assembly.
Members of the assembly were allegedly armed with sticks ('soti').
They allegedly trespassed into the house of the complainant (Respondent No. 2).
They allegedly assaulted the complainant and his wife, Gurmeet Kaur.
Specifically, it was alleged that the appellant outraged the modesty of Gurmeet Kaur (Section 354 IPC).
It was further alleged that the appellant snatched the gold earrings ('walis') worn by Gurmeet Kaur by using force (implicating Section 379B IPC).
The accused allegedly threatened to kill the complainant and his wife (Section 506 IPC).
The appellant's application for anticipatory bail was rejected by the Sessions Court.

The High Court also rejected the anticipatory bail application, noting the seriousness of the allegations, particularly Sections 354 and 379B IPC, and the need for custodial interrogation for recovery of the snatched earrings and the weapons used.
The Supreme Court heard the appeal challenging the High Court's rejection of anticipatory bail.

prosecution_arguments.argument: Denial of anticipatory bail is justified due to seriousness of offenses including house trespass, outraging modesty, and snatching with force.
precedents: State rep. by CBI vs. Anil Sharma (1997) 7 SCC 187
Jai Prakash Singh v. State of Bihar (2012) 4 SCC 379
P. Chidambaram v. Directorate of Enforcement (2019) 9 SCC 24
elements: Prima facie evidence of house trespass (S. 452)
Assault with intent to outrage modesty (S. 354)

counter_arguments.loophole: Allegations may be exaggerated due to prior enmity
supporting_precedents: Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar (2014) 8 SCC 273
Siddharam Satlingappa Mhetre v. State of Maharashtra (2011) 1 SCC 694

prosecution_arguments.argument: Custodial interrogation needed for recovery of earrings and weapons
precedents: State rep. by CBI vs. Anil Sharma (1997) 7 SCC 187
Sumitha Pradeep v. Arun Kumar C.K. (2022) SCC OnLine SC 1529

counter_arguments.loophole: No evidence custodial interrogation is only method
supporting_precedents: Gurbaksh Singh Sibbia vs State of Punjab (1980) 2 SCC 565
Siddharam Satlingappa Mhetre v. State of Maharashtra (2011) 1 SCC 694

defense_arguments.argument: Allegations are false/exaggerated due to pre-existing dispute
precedents: Siddharam Satlingappa Mhetre v. State of Maharashtra (2011) 1 SCC 694

precedents: Gurbaksh Singh Sibbia vs State of Punjab (1980) 2 SCC 565

reasoning: Seriousness of offenses under Sections 354 and 379B IPC
Need for custodial interrogation for recovery
No compelling reason to interfere with High Court order
